title: theresa may housing policy election
story: There are all kinds of answers.A social care policy that went down among elderly Tory voters like a cup of cold novichok.A leader who repeated the phrase “strong and stable” so much the record started to scratch.But the statistics tell a simpler story — they lost it because of HOUSING.The voters who drove Labour’s turnout surge were those who used to be able to own homes, but now can’t.This “rentquake”, according to pollster Matt Singh, was enough to explain 77 per cent of the swing to Labour.These young voters are furious. And they’re right to be.As recently as 1991, a third of those aged 16 to 24 owned their own home.Now, that figure is ten per cent.For those aged 25 to 34, the rate has fallen from 66 per cent to 38 per cent.Home ownership rates in Britain are now the fourth lowest in the EU, and we have the second highest proportion of social housing, i.e., people living in homes provided by the State.Earlier this year, we at the Centre for Policy Studies commissioned polling asking young people how government could make their lives better.The top answer was clear — they want housing to be more affordable.And not via cheaper rents — by a three-to-one margin, they wanted the Government to prioritise home ownership.Strikingly, only three per cent of those aged 18 to 24 told us they never wanted to own their own home.They just can’t see themselves being able to afford it for years — often decades.This is a crisis with many causes.The persistent failure, stretching back decades, to build enough new homes. A dysal planning system.Existing homeowners who don’t want their communities disrupted or their views spoiled.A Labour government that made it much easier for buy-to-let landlords to snap up those homes that were being built, and much harder for first-time buyers to do the same — and a financial crash which made that problem so much worse. Yet it’s also a crisis with many solutions.Making it easier to extend or expand existing properties. Changing Green Belt regulations so we protect our most beautul countryside while building on pig farms, or beside railway stations or motorways or electricity substations or other decidedly non-green and unpleasant bits of land.Finding ways  to turn renters into owners, as Margaret Thatcher did with the Right to Buy for council tenants in the 1980s, with more than a little success.But the sad truth is that while the Government has succeeded in dragging up construction levels, it is still not thinking anywhere near radically enough.“Since my very first day in Downing Street, I have made it my personal mission to fix our broken housing system,” Theresa May told the National Housing Federation yesterday.But that mission is in grave jeopardy.A year ago, the Prime Minister endured a triple whammy of embarrassment in her party conference speech — being handed a P45 by a prankster, developing a crippling cough, then seeing the slogan behind her start to fall off.Mrs May bravely endured these trials. But she could do little about the fact that her promise in the same speech to “make the British dream a reality by igniting home ownership once again” was built around a £10billion expansion of the Help to Buy scheme.A scheme which pretty much every economist, including the Government’s own Office for Budget Responsibility, says is mostly serving to push up house prices and make colossally rich housebuilders even richer.Indeed, even as Mrs May was speaking, their collective share price spiked by £1BILLION.Yesterday, the Prime Minister ed to the subject.In a speech to the National Housing Summit, she promised another £2billion for social housing.But even on its own terms, Mrs May’s proposal isn’t a blunderbuss.It’s a pinprick. Not only is the £2billion spread over a decade but it’s a small fraction of the amount that George Osborne cut from the same budgets.And it fits a wider pattern. For all the Government’s rhetoric, the big ideas to get Britain building just aren’t there.One of the keys to David Cameron’s election victory in 2015 — right there on the first page of the Tory manesto — was a promise to extend the Right to Buy to housing associations and to build 200,000 starter homes.The commitment was to create two million more homeowners within five years.As of May 2018, not a single one of those starter homes had been built — and the expansion of Right to Buy is still lodged in the gullet of the Whitehall machine.It’s the same pattern on planning reform.Sajid Javid’s robust proposals as Communities Secretary to break up the oligopoly of the big housebuilders, free up more land and speed up development — all badly needed — were neutered by Downing Street, because it was paranoid about upsetting traditional Tory voters who don’t like the sight of bulldozers.When the Government’s new planning framework was announced in March, the headlines were about building more and higher-quality homes.But the small print made it so that councils could get away with building fewer houses, not more.I don’t doubt that Mrs May’s heart is in the right place.But  she and her team don’t pluck up their courage on housing — and take far more dramatic steps both to build more houses and create more homeowners — they’ll almost certainly lose the next election. More than that, they’ll deserve to.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: rod liddle immigration post brexit
story: Immigration. A vexed issue. Complain about it and people will call you a racist.That’s a popular way of shutting down debate these days. Just screech “raaacisst” at someone.I’d go so far as to say it’s one of the reasons Leave won the referendum — because ordinary people were sick of being called racist when they simply worried about the millions of people who have arrived here in the past ten years.About seven million, in fact. An astonishing number.The Prime Minister is about to draw up her plans for immigration post-Brexit.She will be taking advice from the Migration Advisory Committee . It has suggested we allow in skilled workers who might be vital to our economy.It has also suggested we clamp down on low-skilled migrants.This seems to me a perfectly sensible argument. We should not entirely close ourselves off from the world. And there are foreign nationals here who do excellent work for our country. And pay good taxes.At the same time, the vast influx of low-skilled workers has had a terrible effect upon our country.Some towns — such as Boston in Lincolnshire — have been effectively taken over.And as the MAC found, the vast reservoir of labour has depressed the wages of British people at the lowest end of the scale. It has hurt the poorest of us.But it doesn’t only hurt us. You’ll have seen the squalid conditions in which a lot of these low-paid foreign workers live. This is exploitation, on a massive scale.How any leftie can support it absolutely befoggles me.Living below the minimum wage, crammed into rotten accommodation — all so companies such as Amazon can make a bigger profit.No wonder the big companies were the first to complain. Listen: Pay your workers a decent, living wage in future and shut up, huh?But this is an overcrowded country. It is ludicrous to suggest that the millions we have allowed in have not had a massive effect on our infrastructure.It’s why we need to pave over more and more of the countryside to build homes, for example. The MAC suggested house prices had risen as a consequence — and our homes already cost too much.There’s pressure on our schools, our hospitals and our transport networks.Well, with any luck this will all come to an end. Perhaps the Government might also abide by its pledge to get yearly immigration levels down to the tens of thousands, rather than the hundreds of thousands as it is at the moment.But at the same time we should look after the EU migrants we have already let in, and ensure they feel secure and safe living in Britain.Do all that and I’ll be a happy man. Even  the lefties still shriek “raaacisst” every few seconds.GIRLS – looking for something to wear for a night out? You’ll find it in a drawer in your kitchen.They come in rolls for about £1.50 from Asda. Yep, it’s the black bin liner, as sported here by Megan Barton Hanson.I have no idea, incidentally, who Megan Barton Hanson is, still less her boyfriend called “Wes”.BBC Radio 6 presenter Cerys Matthews says she refuses to play music made by people who went to private school.OK, Cerys. That means your entire back catalogue is banned, seeing as you were educated at the expensive St Michael’s School in Llanelli.A few weeks ago a BBC executive said he wouldn’t be commissioning comedies from public schoolboys .Spouting every right-on opinion that suddenly swings into fashion?Here’s a tip, Cerys. Play the best rock, folk and soul music you can find.The stuff that sounds the most interesting.You’ll find that auto- matically the private school musicians will be excluded anyway – including yourself.APPARENTLY President Trump’s penis closely resembles a toadstool.This is according to Stormy Daniels, who says she had an affair with Donald.The question is, though – what kind of toadstool?There are hundreds of thousands of species. Was it a fly agaric? That’s the one with a big red head covered in white spots. If so, Donald ought to get himself to a doctor.Or maybe it’s that one with a thin stalk and a big yellow head the size of a dinner plate.If so, Stormy had better get herself to a doctor.A “RELATIONSHIP expert” has warned us all about dodgy body language  we’re out on a date.Tracey Cox says we shouldn’t fidget, for a start. What, even  we’ve taken her to a ballet?Also, don’t wring your hands or sit in a slumped manner, and so on.Hmm. As a “relationship expert” I offer the following advice to blokes out on a first date in a restaurant.2. Don’t pass wind then waft the air saying “Mmmmm, Bisto!”3. When they bring the black pepper, don’t sneeze on her pasta.4. If you do sneeze on her pasta, stir it around a bit when she’s not looking.5. Don’t use a bread stick to excavate the contents of your ear.6. Don’t keep checking the football scores on your phone. And shouting loudly: “Lee Gregory! 85th minute! Get IN you f***er!”7. Don’t ask the lady at the next table  she’s up for a threesome.Follow that stuff and you can fidget away to your heart’s delight. You’ll be OK.THERE’S a crisis in our wildle. Some of our favourite species of birds or mammals are on the brink of extinction.The corn bunting, for example, and the hedgehog.As TV wildle campaigner Chris Packham rightly says, this is because we have paved over the countryside to build ever more homes.And because of the intensive farming methods – which have seen the eradication of farmland birds.Packham has drawn up a “People’s Manesto for Wildle” which includes stuff like twinning city schools with farms, so that kids grow up with an understanding of nature.There’s also a demo at Hyde Park in London on Saturday. I’ll be there. Don’t forget – as Joni Mitchell once sang, you don’t know what you’ve got ’til its gone.SO, it looks very much as  the old Irish border problem is going to be solved very quickly after all.We’re close to agreeing a deal with the European Union which will enable Northern Ireland to retain its “soft border”.The Remainers said it couldn’t be done. Totally impossible. But  we don’t want a hard border and the Irish don’t want a hard border – who is going to make us have one?Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: uber eats customers face delays after riders go on strike and start ignoring mcdonalds orders after rate splash
story: Groups of unhappy couriers stood by their mopeds and scooters throughout London, as they protested over their wages.Hungry customers craving a Big Mac and fries complained they waited for hours for orders that never came.One person even reported eventually going to their nearby McDonalds to get what they had tried to order, and found a group of drivers milling around outside the branch.They tweeted: Thanks @UberEats for such wonderful service. Order confirmed at 2.20. Still waiting for it at 3.30.Call the office and they say there is not enough drivers. Turn up to the same McDonald’s and there is 12 of them sitting outside. Brilliant service.Various McDonalds in London saw drivers parked up and refusing to carry out deliveries.While outside the Uber headquarters dozens of vehicles were left in protest, as drivers turned off their engines and demonstrated their fury.Another customer posted: My order has taken 90 minutes now and is still ‘preparing’, what can I do about this?She was soon advised: Cancel it. Uber messed with there drivers pay and there all on strike. I waited 2 hours for them to just cancel.The new minimum delivery fee has been reduced, as has the order minimum - which now sits at £3.50.Drivers want the fees and boost policy - where they would get more money in certain areas at certain times - to be revised to the former rates.Dozens refused to log in to work, or deliver any food yesterday, as they claim their earnings got chopped in half.A disgruntled Twitter user, who appears to be a driver, wrote: Uber drivers are striking and not picking up orders. Forced most McDonald’s delivery machines offline.Protests outside Uber’s head office.Thanks for cutting our pay by almost 50 per cent! Unacceptable!A spokesman for Uber said: We recently asked couriers for feedback on how we could help maximise their earnings.In response we’re making some changes to our payment structure in Birmingham, London and Manchester, which also bring these cities more in line with the rest of the UK.The changes will help increase courier earnings during busy mealtimes, while providing more transparency on when and where the potential to earn is highest.To provide couriers with confidence the new system will improve earnings during the busiest times, we’re also introducing minimum payment guarantees of £9-11 an hour. Making improvements in response to courier feedback is a top priority, such as the sickness, injury, maternity and paternity protections we recently introduced.Our door is always open for inidual couriers to speak to us about any issues theyre having.A McDonalds spokeswoman directed the Sun Online to Uber for comment on the protests, but added nothing on delivery impact had been flagged specically to them through their customer services channels.Couriers went on strike in Scotland earlier this month in protest over the planned wage change.And in 2016 and 2017 drivers and couriers demonstrated against pay cuts.

title: high speed hose treat prostate
story: It shoots a saline solution guided by a robot into the prostate in minutes rather than the patient having to spend a night in hospital.Millions of older men commonly struggle with a condition known as benign prostate hypertrophy — causing problems with urinating.The prostate gland becomes enlarged and presses on the tube that takes urine from the bladder.The speedy new hose treatment could bring relief to many sufferers.Guidance published by the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence said: “This procedure uses a specialised system for the targeted heat-free removal of prostate tissue with the patient under general or spinal anaesthesia. “A probe is inserted through the urethra and into the bladder where its position is confirmed using a computer.”It added: “The old procedure normally involved an overnight stay in hospital.”Clinical trials for the “hosepipe” are still on-going and more evidence will be available about the treatment next year.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: gas safety week parents tragic girl
story: Without regular checks and servicing, a boiler or any other gas appliance could leak toxic carbon monoxide – putting you and your family’s lives at risk.To mark Gas Safety Week, three readers speak to LYNSEY HOPE about their boiler disasters. They are urging you to get yours serviced and to install audible carbon monoxide monitors in your home.It might just save a le.Schoolgirl Katie Overton went to bed excited about her little sister’s birthday party next day — but tragically the family never got to celebrate.The next morning, the 11-year-old was found dead in her bed, having been poisoned by carbon monoxide which had leaked from a faulty boiler at her home.Stepdad Paul recalls: “We’d been busy getting ready for Emma’s fth birthday party. We’d been baking cakes and blowing up balloons.“We went to bed as normal that night. In the morning we all got up and cracked on with the arrangements and we thought Katie was having a lie-in.“The house seemed very quiet. I popped out and when I came home, Katie still wasn’t up.“We were used to her having a lie-in at the weekend, but we felt something was wrong.”Mum Debra, 47, went up to Katie’s bedroom at the family’s rented terraced house in Southsea, Hants.Paul, 53, recalls: “Debs called out to me that she’d been sick in her bed. I ran upstairs and she was lying there, motionless.“I started shaking her, trying to rouse her. She wasn’t responding. Her body was cold.“I told Debs to call 999 and I spoke to paramedics on the phone. They told me to try mouth-to-mouth, but her jaw was locked. I knew then she was dead.“We had no idea why or what had happened. All of us were in a state of shock.”An ambulance rushed Katie to Queen Alexandra Hospital in Portsmouth, but within half an hour a doctor confirmed the family’s worst fears.Paul says: “He said there was nothing they could do for her. There was no obvious cause of death.“All we could think was that she’d been sick in her sleep and choked on it.“Because it was an unexplained death, we had CID come to the house. They asked us all sorts of questions, whether Katie had been having any problems at school.“They took away the mattress as evidence and the four of us were left in the house, with no idea the gas was still leaking.”To make matters even worse, rumours circulated around the area that Paul and Debra had murdered their daughter.Paul says: “A friend of Debra’s told us there were some lies going around. There was a lot of stares and whispering behind our backs.“It was incredibly hard to deal with, as we were grieving for Katie.“We were in a state of shock. She was a perfectly healthy girl and she seemed fine when she went to bed the night before.”Post-mortems do not routinely check for carbon monoxide poisoning, so no cause of death was given to her family.But around ten days later, Debra woke Paul early one morning complaining of a strong smell of fumes.He recalls: “I had a splitting headache and the house stank. I felt dizzy and sick.“I phoned our letting agent and said we thought something was seriously wrong with the boiler. An engineer came out and said he was going to put a carbon monoxide monitor by the boiler and we all had to leave the house. He left it running for ten minutes before going back in to grab it. He ran back out again and said, ‘I can’t believe any of you are alive.’“There was a lethal amount of carbon monoxide in the house. He kept saying he was surprised we were still alive.“I asked him  he thought it might have caused Katie’s death and he said, ‘Possibly’.” Paul phoned the police and even though Katie’s body had been cremated, they still had some blood samples. They later tested positive for carbon monoxide.An investigation revealed that faulty pipework on the boiler had been allowing the toxic gas to escape into Katie’s bedroom. Paul has been campaigning for tighter regulations to prevent deaths from carbon monoxide poisoning ever since Katie’s death in March 2003.She says: “He seemed very poorly. He didn’t have a temperature but he kept falling asleep and he’d vomit.“Then, I’d find him asleep in the dining room in a really strange position. Something just didn’t feel right.”The same morning, the carbon monoxide alarm at her home in Strood, Kent, started beeping. She says: “It wasn’t the continuous warning alarm but it was beeping as  it had run out of batteries.“I guess it just made me think and I had a niggling feeling it might be something to do with carbon monoxide. I rushed Aaden-James to A&ampE. They took a blood sample and within five minutes he was on oxygen. He had to spend a couple of days in hospital.“Fortunately, he is OK and there are no lasting effects.”Tests later revealed the gas was leaking from pipes at the top of the boiler.Kirstein says: “If you don’t have a carbon monoxide alarm, get one now. I had one before, now I have three.”But latest figures show there are still around 50 fatalities a year in the UK.He says: “Fteen years on and the basic laws haven’t changed and people are still dying.“Katie’s death was preventable. We didn’t have a carbon monoxide alarm in the house.“We are all now living with a sadness that will never go away.”Paul adds that the tragedy has been particularly hard on Katie’s sisters, Sian, now 22, and Emma, 21.He says: “We want to make people aware of the dangers of carbon monoxide so no more families lose someone like we have.“Sometimes people will say to me, ‘It’s OK, I haven’t got gas, I’ve got a wood-burning stove.’“But carbon monoxide is produced by all solid fuels that burn. There are more carbon monoxide alarms around now than when Katie died, but in England, the law says they only have to be in properties that burn solid fuel.THE Sun is offering you the chance to win one of five brand new Ariston boilers worth more than £1,000 each.The Ariston Clas Net ONE comes with an industry-leading 12-year warranty.To be in with a chance of winning see thesun/aristoncompetition and answer two simple questions.“In Scotland, they have to be in all properties. The law in England needs changing — everyone should have one.“What about older properties? They often don’t have alarms. And what about your neighbour? We lived in a terraced house — the people next door may well have been poisoned as well.“Carbon monoxide goes straight through the brickwork. Please make sure you install an audible alarm in your home. If we’d had one, we would have been alerted to the gas and our beautul Katie would still be with us.”Paul also warns that gas safety ­certicates are not a substitute for ­having appliances regularly serviced.He says: “You can get a certicate without having a service. Of course, a lot of people choose this asSue, 45, had moved into a new-build home in Sale, Grt Manchester, with son Josh and now ex-husband Paul in 2003.She says: “I worked at home running a building firm. I’d get headaches and be queasy, dizzy and fatigued. I put it down to stress. I was forgetful, but thought I was getting dementia. Josh was six. He’d get stomach and head pains.Three years later, Sue was admitted to hospital TWICE with chest pain – and once collapsed – but each time doctors misdiagnosed cocaine abuse, let her rest then discharged her.“No one mentioned carbon monoxide and I wasn’t tested,” she says. But the warranty on her boiler then expired and Paul called an engineer, who found the leaky flue under the lounge floor.Sue still suffers memory, migraine and rheumatic trouble while Josh has poor concentration, and she thinks her family only survived because Paul would open windows a lot. She warns: “With smoke you get a warning but with CO there is no taste or smell. It is a silent killer.”“But what it means is that all these years after Katie’s death, an engineer can walk into a house, have a look at the flame and say, ‘Yes it’s burning a nice blue and it is safe.’“It gives you a false confidence. All gas appliances need to be serviced as per the manufacturers’ guidelines.“And get it done now, don’t wait until November when engineers are busy. It could save a le.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: sun says housing revolution
story: The latest cash injection is derisory.The Government is trumpeting £2billion of new funding for housing associations over six years from 2022. That’s just 7,000 homes a year nationwide.Our population is increasing by almost 400,000 a year. The annual ­target for new homes is 300,000 — and we doubt even that would lower prices enough for young people to afford to buy in London and the South East.In fairness, the total HAS risen to 217,000 a year, the most since 2007. But it’s still way short — and the Government’s remedies are woefully timid.Sajid Javid promised a huge shake-up when he ran housing. He was knocked back by the negativity from Philip Hammond’s Treasury. Then he moved on.We need to slash planning restrictions and defy obstructive NIMBYs. We need to stop the land-banking that sees developers hoard plots or release homes at a snail’s pace to keep prices high.We need more cash help for small builders. We should borrow billions, build affordable homes on public land and sell them at a profit for the Treasury.The Tories need to wake up or housing will sink them. Instead they are hyping up some footling new funding that only partly reverses a previous cut.It fools no one.WHY is the EU wasting time pressing for a border between Britain and Northern ­Ireland? It’s a non-starter.No Government could consider it. Especially not one entirely reliant on the votes of those most vehemently opposed to splitting up the UK, the DUP.This cannot be news to Brussels. They cannot believe Theresa May will surrender and collapse her Government.Why persist with it? The answer must be: to run down the clock — until, at the last minute, Mrs May agrees virtually anything to avoid a No Deal.Which is why Donald Tusk also still insists key areas of our wildly over-generous Chequers offer must be “reworked”.Mrs May has gone as far as she can. title: dup ian paisley keeps seat recall petition
story: The North Antrim DUP politician, who is helping to prop up Theresa May, was suspended for failing to declare two holidays paid for by the Sri Lankan government.He narrowly avoided a by-election after fewer than 10 per cent of constituents signed the petition.The petition device, created in the wake of the Westminster expenses scandal, was initiated after Mr Paisley was banned from the House of Commons over his South Asian holidays.A parliamentary watchdog found in July that a year after the trips, Mr Paisley lobbied then prime minister David Cameron not to support a UN probe into alleged Sri Lankan human rights abuses.In a statement, Mr Paisley last night said: In July I apologised for a mistake made almost six years ago.The electorate was asked to pass judgement. 90.6% have accepted my apology. The electorate has clearly spoken.I would like to thank my true friends, family, the electorate who have stood by me with unwavering support. Hallelujah.The long-standing Democratic Unionist, whose late father the Reverend Ian Paisley founded the party, is currently suspended from the DUP pending its own internal investigation into his conduct.Northern Irelands Chief Electoral Officer Virginia McVea announced the outcome in Belfast around 1.25am this morning after a count that commenced at midnight.Ulster Unionist leader Robin Swann said it was clear there was no public appetite for a by-election, saying he respected that outcome.He added: However I would caution Ian Paisley not to see this as some sort of victory or endorsement of his actions in acting as a paid advocate for a foreign government and bringing North Antrim and the House of Commons into disrepute.Rather I would urge him to use the time that he has been suspended from Parliament and the DUP, to reflect on the severity of what he has done and the embarrassment he has brought on Northern Ireland. He should demonstrate some humility.Mr Paisleys Commons ban has left Theresa May shorn of one of her 10 DUP MP confidence and supply allies during a period that could witness several crucial Brexit votes.An investigation by the Parliamentary Commissioner for Standards found the cost of the hospitality afforded Mr Paisley and his family may have been signicantly more than his £50,000 estimate.It found the Sri Lankan holidays included business-class air travel, accommodation at first-class hotels, helicopter trips and visits to tourist attractions for the North Antrim MP and his wider family.The trips also included meeting with Sri Lankan governmental figures.Mr Paisleys threshold for registering such hospitality in 2013 was around £660.

title: longjawed orbweavers spider web greece come to uk
story: One major sub-species, the Tetragnatha, is also known as the stretch spider because of its creepy long legs. Heres all you need to know about the bug.They are found all over the world although most thrive in warmer climates in the tropics and subtropics.They are commonly called stretch spiders because of their eerier elongated body form.When disturbed they will stretch their front legs forward — while they jut their other six legs backwards.This allows them to hide on blades of grass or similar elongated pieces of foliage like twigs and leaves.They are so light and nimble that they are able to run over water and chose the waters edge as their preferred habitat.The name Tetragnatha is derived from Greek, tetra — a numerical prefix referring to four and gnatha meaning jaw.One of the biggest and most common species is T. extensa.It can be found near lakes, river banks or swamps.Large numbers of iniduals can often be found in reeds, tall grass or minor trees and shrubs.In September 2018 locals in the Greece island-town of Aitoliko woke to find a massive 300m-long spiders web along the shore.The huge web was spun overnight across shrubs and bushes lining the sea-front.Unseasonably warm weather was thought to be behind the extraordinary behaviour.Maria Chatzaki, a professor of molecular biology and genetics, told Newsit.gr: Its as  the spiders are taking advantage of these conditions and are having a kind of a party.They mate, they reproduce and provide a whole new generation.These spiders are not dangerous for humans and will not cause any damage to the areas flora.The spiders will have their party and will soon die.Longjawed Orbweavers are found all over the world apart from arctic or desert conditions.While they prefer more tropical and humid conditions, they do already live in the UK.

title: eu bitterly divided on whether to compromise with theresa may on brexit as leaders scrutinise chequers plan without her at crunch summit
story: Mrs May is gearing up for the leaders of the other 27 countries to scrutinise her Chequers plan without her, after she warned last night she would not delay our EU exit in any circumstances.Some reports say that a rebel group led by the Netherlands and Belgium - and backed by European Council President Donald Tusk - are more keen to compromising with Britain over our EU exit.But Michel Barnier, along with the leaders of France and Germany, are standing firm in their positions on the Irish border.Today President Macron insisted: We have to remain united and consistent with what we want.. what we need is an agreement with the backstop for our Irish friends.But Mrs May demanded yesterday the EU drop their hardline demands on the border in Ireland, telling them that it would effectively ide up the UK and keep Northern Ireland in the bloc after we leave.Irish PM Leo Varadkar, who Mrs May met with this morning, said the EU was very united around our view that we need to protect the integrity of the single market.However, Hungarian leader Viktor Orban said he wasnt part of the group in the bloc which believed the EU should punish Britain.He said: The other camp of prime ministers they would like to deliver evidence that to make that kind of decision is to be punished and the British must suffer. I don’t like that approach at all. What we need is a fair Brexit and good cooperation between UK and EU in future.Jean Claude Juncker appeared to be on the fence, telling reporters that Mrs Mays 10-minute speech at dinner was polite, it was not aggressive, she was doing her job.This morning Mrs May had meetings with other leaders - including Angela Merkel and a series of other leaders.Mr Tusk this morning posted a sassy snap on his Instagram of him offering the PM a bit of cake, with the caption: A piece of cake, perhaps? Sorry, no cherries.Ahead of Theresa Mays crunch summit in Salzburg, the PMs of Malta and the Czech Republic took the unusual step of calling for a fresh referendum on leaving the EU.Ignoring the clear will of the 17million Brits who opted to break free of the bloc in 2016, Andrej Babiš, the eurosceptic Czech prime minister, told the BBC he was “very unhappy that the UK is leaving and maybe it would be better to make another referendum”.And Joseph Muscat, the Maltese PM, said most of the other EU leaders agreed, and wanted to make the almost impossible happen.I think most of us would welcome a situation where there is the possibility of the British people, putting things into perspective, and then deciding once and for all, he added.But last night the PM told EU leaders there was not going to be another vote.The Brexit talks are deadlocked over the issue of the Irish border.Brussels wants an operational backstop in place to prevent a so-called hard border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland after Brexit.But that would effectively keep Northern Ireland in the EUs single market and customs union.Theresa May simply wont accept this because it will effectively break up the UK and put a virtual border in the Irish sea.And it will infuriate her coalition partners, the DUP, too, who she relies on to win votes in the House of Commons.A new plan by Mr Barnier – revealed by The Sun on Saturday – to police the new customs border between Britain and Northern Ireland with invisible technology has also been thrown out by No10.Britain wants an agreement to not be needed, by agreeing a close partnership with the EU which would make the backstop void.Last night Mrs May told leaders last night that her Chequers plan was the only credible one that could work for both sides, but called on them to evolve their position and compromise like she has done.And she slapped down calls for a second referendum, saying she must deliver on the vote for the British people.I want to be absolutely clear - this Government will never accept a second referendum, she said.Her remarks came as:Later today the leaders will discuss security matters - and Mrs May will update leaders on the Salisbury poisoning investigation.Then she will leave them to have lunch and discuss in detail her Chequers plan without her.Yesterday Mr Tusk dealt her a blow by saying she would have to rework it in some way for it to be accepted by the bloc.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: where are we at with brexit your questions answered
story: This is largely because charity rescue vessels are finding it harder and harder to operate because Italy will not let them dock.The migration issue continues to fuel a political crisis across the continent.So it will be a key focus  for EU leaders.The president of the European Council, Donald Tusk, said in a letter to fellow leaders: "The quest to end the migration crisis is a common task of all the member states and EU institutions."If some want to solve the crisis, while others want to use it, it will remain unsolvable."I am hoping that in Salzburg we will be able to put an end to the mutual resentment and  to a constructive approach.":: So what about Brexit? Will it be discussed?Absolutely. To some extent the summit has morphed into a key Brexit staging post.There won't be any formal conclusions or formal changes to the position of the EU - this is an informal summit and the rigidity of EU processes mean they cannot suddenly change course.But there could be subtle indicators of positions being moulded.:: Any key moments to look out for?Yes - at the leaders dinner Theresa May had 10 minutes to state the UK position.It's the first time that the leaders have all met as one since Britain's Chequers proposal  was revealed back in July. She eyeballed her colleagues with a detailed explanation of what that means.She is understood to have told them that neither side can demand the unacceptable of the other and she told them that there would be no second referendum in the UK and no delay to the UK's departure. Towards the end of the summit the 27 remaining members of the EU will meet without Mrs May to discuss Brexit.After that President Tusk and Mrs May will have a 10 minute meeting.There she will hear, in private, what the 27 think, collectively, of her position. Immediately afterwards she will give a news conference.:: Are the two sides really worried about there being a 'no-deal' clf-edge withdrawal?Yes. President Tusk made that very clear in his letter to EU leaders: "Unfortunately, a no deal scenario is still quite possible. But  we all act responsibly, we can avoid a catastrophe."In my sideline chats, EU and UK diplomats are even more blunt. A "no-deal" by accident is unnecessarily possible - each blames the other's intransigence.At the main summit - the remaining 27 EU leaders will meet without Mrs May but with EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier to discuss what they call the "state of play" of the negotiations.,targeting:" data-targeting-strnativekey="" data-targeting-platform="" data-tag="" data-component-name="sdc-site-mpu" aria-label="Advertisement" id="mpu-inline-mobile" data-tolerance="2"It prompted the resignation of then Brexit secretary David Davis and foreign secretary Boris Johnson, both of whom thought the proposal did not deliver the Brexit people voted for.And the EU side has consistently said Chequers isn't workable because it ides the integrity of the EU's single market by "cherry picking" the favourable parts of it.:: What's holding things up?There are two singular and distinct problems holding up the Brexit process.The first is part of the orce deal - the actual process of Brexit - and it's the "Irish backstop" problem.Britain has committed to leaving the single market and the customs union.By definition that means checks need to take place at hard borders between the UK and the EU unless or until some sort of mutual trade deal can be established. It is known as the "backstop" because it is a fallback position that the EU insists must be "legally operable" in case no better arrangement in the form of a trade deal  materialises.But it is a problem on the island of Ireland where no one wants to see the a  of hard borders between the north and the south.The EU's answer is for Northern Ireland to remain in the EU customs union. They say that checks can take place as goods pass between the British mainland and Northern Ireland and point out some agricultural checks already take place.The UK says that is not possible because putting Northern Ireland in a separate customs zone breaks up the constitutional integrity of the United Kingdom. The second problem relates to the framework for the future relationship. This needs to be ironed out and put in a formal text - a political declaration - as part of the Brexit process.However the British Chequers proposal for the future relationship does not fly with the EU side.They think it represents a partial customs union on goods but no customs union on services and no freedom of movement.That, for Brussels, is cherry picking and undermines the integrity of the EU - other countries will want the same they fear and the whole single market/customs union project falls apart.It is quite easy to find compromise on the political declaration or to fudge it and deal with it later, post-Brexit day. It's much harder with the Irish backstop which is more binary and immediate.:: How's the relationship between the two sides?Not great. The British perception that the EU side isn't budging despite signicant compromises on their part is a source of huge frustration.The EU is angered by suggestions in the UK, by the Brexit secretary and prime minister no less, that they won't pay the "exit bill"   there is no deal.The EU was alarmed by Michael Gove's suggestion that whatever deal is done on the future framework, it can always be unravelled after Brexit day. .

title: brexit news theresa signals ready
story: NewsBrexit news: Theresa May signals she's ready to strip Britain from EU without deal unless bloc backs herEU chief Donald Tusk slapped down the Prime Minister’s blueprint as leaders arrived for a crunch showdown in SalzburgShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy political editor06:00, 20 SEP 2018Updated08:29, 20 SEP 2018NewsTheresa May meeting the Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz last night "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheresa May signalled she was ready to strip Britain from the EU without a deal unless bloc leaders back her Brexit plan tonight. EU chief Donald Tusk slapped down the Prime Minister’s blueprint as leaders arrived for a crunch showdown in Salzburg. But, over dinner in the Austrian city, Mrs May indicated the UK would walk away  EU bosses fail to support her Chequers proposal by mid-November. She said: “We all recognise that time is short but delaying or extending these negotiations is not an option. “I know that for many of you Brexit is not something you want but it’s important to be clear that there will be no second referendum in the UK.  “The public has delivered its verdict and I as Prime Minister will deliver upon that. “The UK will leave on March 29 next year.” The PM also warned EU leaders not to split the UK as a solution to customs arrangements on Northern Ireland's border with the Republic, which forms the UK's only land frontier with the EU. She said: “The Commission's proposal for this protocol – that I should assent to a legal separation of the United Kingdom into two customs territories - is not credible.” Brexiteers and Remainers have blasted her proposal, known as the Chequers plan because it was agreed at the PM’s country retreat. But, speaking over a slap-up meal of cream cheese with a tomato and courgette salad, followed by Viennese schnitzel with parsley potatoes, she insisted: “I believe I have put forward serious and workable proposals. “We will of course not agree on every detail but I hope that you will respond in kind. “The onus is now on all of us to get this deal done.”  Earlier, EU Council President Donald Tusk dealt the latest hammer blow to the PM’s favoured withdrawal plan. Hours before her RAF jet even landed in the Austrian Alps, where the Sound of Music was set, he welcomed a “positive evolution” in Britain’s position, “as well as the will to minimise the negative effects of Brexit”. But he added: “On other issues, such as the Irish question or the framework for economic cooperation, the UK’s proposals will need to be reworked and further negotiated.” Revealing plans for an emergency EU Brexit summit in November, Mr Tusk warned: “Today there is perhaps more hope but there is surely less less and time.” EU Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker claimed the EU and Uk were “far away”.

title: calamitous tory chris grayling refuses
story: NewsCalamitous Tory Chris Grayling refuses to resign as rail chaos report finds 'nobody took charge'It comes after a scathing watchdog verdict on disruption on Thameslink and Northern RailShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByMark EllisDan BloomOnline Political Editor09:27, 20 SEP 2018Updated10:12, 20 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/video/chris-grayling-refuses-resign-amid-13278201,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCalamity-prone Tory Chris Grayling has refused to resign despite a damning report into this summer's rail chaos finding nobody took charge. The government today launched the biggest review of the railways since privatisation after a scathing watchdog verdict on disruption on Thameslink and Northern Rail. But asked by the BBC  he would consider his position Mr Grayling said: My job, my position, is to get this sorted. Instead he blamed fragmented decision making and said: I’m not going to point the finger at iniduals. It's a system problem, it's the way the whole industry works, that's what the review says. Mr Grayling has spent six years in the Cabinet, one of the longest-serving current ministers round the table, despite being infamous for his failed policies.   He held the Justice Secretary job for less than three years yet his prisoner book ban, court fees and a training deal with Saudi Arabia have all been ditched.   A &pound23m prisoner tracking scheme he unveiled was also axed, while the Court of Appeal slammed another legal aid cut that forced domestic violence victims to show evidence to get a lawyer.  The Office of Rail and Road  today published its report into what went wrong with the biggest rail timetable change in a generation, which was introduced in May. It blamed rail industry “failures” for the chaos which caused misery for passengers, but also said Mr Grayling's Department for Transport  was aware of the risks and its slow response aggravated the challenge of rewriting the timetable. The report added: Had the final decision by DfT to phase the introduction of services been aligned with the schedule for developing the timetable in August 2017, the unpredicted consequences for the Thameslink timetable may have been avoided and the consequential risks of a timetabling failure on the scale experienced would have been greatly reduced.  Mr Grayling also refused today to heed Labour's calls for rail nationalisation. He claimed that since privatisation the railways have enjoyed unprecedented growth and success and we’re now a victim of that success. The Tory minister told Sky News: I’m very much a believer in public-private partnership… it’s not that state ownership is a panacea. However, he added: I think now the structure that was created 25 years ago in which you have fragmentation of track and train in dferent parts of the industry is no longer delivering for passengers. Train operators, Network Rail and the Department for Transport and even ORR itself were all criticised for making mistakes in the hard-hitting report, which came nearly two months after Transport Secretary Chris Grayling told MPs: ”I don’t run the railways.” The hapless cabinet minister dubbed ‘failing’ Grayling shunted blame for the rail timetable chaos into the sidings when he appeared before the all-party Commons Transport Select Committtee. Today - in the wake of the report - Mr Grayling announced a wide-ranging review into the running of the railways, which came under fire from Labour and rail union leaders. It will be led by Keith Williams - deputy chairman of John Lewis and former chief executive of British Airways - who will be supported by an external panel. But Andy McDonald, Labour’s Shadow Transport Secretary, said: “Rail passengers don’t need another review from the Tories to tell them that rail is broken. Another review is meaningless in a year of rocketing fares, failing franchises and timetabling chaos. “Another review lets Chris Grayling off the hook. The railways need a Labour government which will deliver public ownership of rail.” And Mick Cash, general secretary of the RMT union, said: ”The announcement of yet another so-called ‘independent’ review of a system that is broken beyond repair is a total distraction.  “The railways should be publicly owned, safe, secure and accessible for all and not a vehicle simply for private greed.” He branded the ORR report a “whitewash” that ignored the “dire consequences of nearly twenty five years of privatisation, fragmentation and exploitation on Britain’s railways.” In the timetable chaos passengers on Northern and Thameslink networks were particularly badly hit, leaving tens of thousands stranded by reduced or cancelled services. The ORR report says that during the planning stages the industry placed engineering and planning concerns ahead of serving its passengers, and that was made worse by the poor information train operators provided when disruption happened. It states that a key issue was an apparent gap in industry responsibility and accountability for managing systemic risks, and adds”that needs to change.” Professor Stephen Glaister, inquiry chairman, said:“The May 2018 timetable was meant to offer more services and reliability, but in reality it led to major disruption for passengers. “Central to the issues were that good intentions and over-optimism within the rail industry about its ability to recover missed deadlines left no time to uncover and fix problems.

title: labour vow ban credit card
story: NewsLabour vow to ban credit card betting and TV gambling ads during football matches  Jeremy Corbyn takes powerIt's part of a radical crackdown on the "epidemic" of gambling addiction - which deputy Labour leader Tom Watson brands a "public health emergency"Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor09:46, 20 SEP 2018NewsGambling ads would be banned during live sport on TV "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailGambling ads would be banned during live sport on TV under a Labour government. The party also plans to ban the use of credit cards to place bets which will slash billions of pounds of transactions a year. The pledges come as part of a radical crackdown on the gambling industry designed to tackle an “epidemic” of addiction. Branding problem gambling “a public health emergency”, Deputy Labour Leader Tom Watson said that Labour’s next manesto will also boost NHS resources for research into and treatment of gambling addiction, funded in part from a compulsory 1% levy on operators’ gross gambling yield. Labour will also bring in new rules enabling addicts to tell their banks to block online gambling transactions.  He also repeated Labour’s call for Premier League football clubs to end sponsorship deals with gambling firms, and pledged legislation  they do not act voluntarily. In-play betting has become an increasingly prominent part of the gambling scene in recent years, with TV ads in the run-up to games and during half-time urging punters to place wagers on the next goalscorer or the final result. Labour’s review uncovered concerns that, with instant online betting now widely available via smartphones, the ads may present a risk to gambling addicts, young people and those with mental health problems. Research by Goldsmiths University’s Professor Rachel Cassidy estimated that gambling advertising increased six-fold between 2007 and 2013. And recent analysis found that 17% of all adverts during the football World Cup in Russia were for gambling. Mr Watson said: “Problem gambling is Britain’s hidden epidemic and we must treat it as a public health emergency.

Mike Penning, who helped run Mrs May's Tory leadership campaign, branded her plan drawn up at Chequers as dead as a dodo and demanded she drop it. The comments by the former minister are a blow to the Prime Minister just as she attempts to persuade 27 EU leaders to sign up to her plan at a summit in Salzburg. Mrs May hopes that by mid-November she will have a final deal to bring back to the UK Parliament for a vote by MPs. But Labour could vote against the plan, as could hardline Tory Brexiteers in the European Research Group - who Sir Mike has now joined.  He told the : I’ve come to the conclusion that this ‘put up, shut up’ attitude of the prime minister’s — it’s Chequers or nothing, you do as you’re told or else — is a massive insult, not only to my colleagues but also to the voters. “She is playing a game of Russian roulette with the country.” He added Downing Street is “deluded” to think parliament will back the plan. Hemel Hempstead MP Sir Mike was a minister for seven years, most recently Armed Forces minister, before being dropped by Theresa May in her reshuffle last year.  His comments came as the  reported a dossier was circulating among Tory MPs that contains withering verdicts on a successor to Mrs May. Descriptions reportedly include branding Philip Hammond not a hope and Trade Secretary Liam Fox as fading. Tory MP Nadine Dorries complained: “This is a hoax not a scoop. It has not been written by an MP. If I’m wrong, it’s an MP who came in in ‘17, doesn’t know how a leadership challenge works, isn’t very bright and doesn’t know how to spell the names of ministers. Last night Mrs May shot down calls to renegotiate her Brexit offer, telling EU leaders over dinner: Delaying or extending these negotiations is not an option.  “I know that for many of you Brexit is not something you want but it’s important to be clear that there will be no second referendum in the UK. But EU leaders - some of whom called for a second referendum anyway - suggested the UK needs to budge more, putting forward a situation that would leave an unacceptable border down the Irish Sea. European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker described Theresa May's presentation to EU leaders in Salzburg as interesting. It was polite, it was not aggressive, she was doing her job, he told reporters as he arrived for a second day of talks. The UK's current Brexit plan is based on a deal Theresa May drew up at Chequers, her country retreat, in July 2018. At the time it was seen as a major sht to soft Brexit - prompting hard-Leaver Cabinet ministers David Davis and Boris Johnson to resign. The 'Facilitated Customs Arrangement' is a bid to solve the biggest problem of Brexit - how to stop a hard border between Northern Ireland and either the EU, or the rest of the UK. It would keep the UK closely aligned with the EU in a new free trade area for goods. Under this plan, the UK would share a common rulebook with Brussels for goods, including agricultural and food products. Britain would also collect some, but not all, customs tarfs on the EU's behalf. Parliament would technically keep the right to block future rules. But Tory Brexiteers said this olive branch would useless in practice. They forced Theresa May to amend the plan to say the EU should collects tarfs on the UK's behalf. Mrs May insisted this didn't scupper her plan. But EU chief negotiator Michel Barnier disagreed, and has continued to suggest there will be a border between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK. Remainers and Labour have also opposed the Chequers plan, saying it leaves Britain half-in-half-out of the EU in the worst of all worlds.  With a November deadline to agree a deal with the EU looming, and the plan facing a vote in Parliament after that, the UK is now ramping up plans to leave in March 2019 with no deal.

story: NewsMassive scale of Tory war on social housing revealed as 214,000 rentals slashedEXCLUSIVE: Theresa May boasted that tackling Britain’s housing crisis is her “personal mission” - but these figures show a very dferent pictureShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByAndrew GregoryPolitical Editor20:07, 19 SEP 2018Updated08:34, 20 SEP 2018NewsIndependent housing experts said our findings exposed a “huge drop” in available social housing "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe number of new social rent homes has been slashed by more than 200,000 since the Tories came to power, new figures reveal. In a keynote speech today, Theresa May boasted that tackling Britain’s housing crisis is her “personal mission” in a keynote speech. The PM also claimed that her government has committed billions of pounds to getting more homes built. But shocking statistics buried in an official Government report reveal how the Tories have dramatically cut the amount of new cheaper housing rented out to poverty-stricken Brits. Independent housing experts said our findings exposed a “huge drop” in available social housing.  Labour Shadow Housing Secretary John Healey said the figures proved the Tories have made the housing crisis “worse” not better. When the Tories came to power in 2010, there were 270,000 new homes a year rented out by councils or housing associations to Brits on lower incomes. The following year, in 2011/12, this was cut by 3,000. In 2012/13 the 2010/11 total new homes was slashed by 36,000. Every year since 2010 there have been further cuts to the number of social houses let, according to the report by the Ministry of Housing, Communities and Local Government. By 2016/17, there were 70,000 fewer new social rent homes available compared to 2010. In total, there have been 213,501 fewer cheaper houses since the Tories came to power.

title: muller light addict who eats
story: NewsMuller Light addict who eats up to 24 yogurts a day "devastated" after Slimming World changes Syn valueShe's lost three stone already, so something must be working for her...Share&nbsp&nbspCommentsByNicola OakleyHead of Audience15:14, 19 SEP 2018Updated10:45, 20 SEP 2018NewsNikki has lost almost three stone on Slimming World despite getting through an alarming number of yogurts a day "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Slimming World member who eats up to 24 Muller Lights a day has been left devastated after the weight loss organisation increased the yogurts' 'Syn' value . Mum-of-four Nikki O'Neill, 46, from Bournemouth, says she became addicted to the low-fat snacks - which were previously 'free' to eat on the diet plan - as they satisfied her sweet tooth. She munches her way through six or eight yogurts daily, but says on a bad day she can consume three or four multipacks. Slimming World announced on Monday that Muller Lights now have to be counted as 1 'Syn' each, within a member's daily allowance of between five and 15.  If Nikki continued to eat her way through multipacks, she would now far exceed her maximum Syn allowance before counting any other treats. A plain vanilla Muller Light contains 99 calories per pot, meaning 24 would add up to an intake of 2376 calories in yogurts alone. Despite her addiction, Nikki, who works in a school as a kitchen assistant, has managed to lose a huge amount of weight on the plan.  She told : I'm devastated by the news. I've been doing Slimming World for five and a half months and I've lost almost three stone. I never liked yogurts until I joined. I have a sweet tooth so I soon realised that this would be a great replacement for sugary snacks. Most people on Slimming World might have one or two low fat yogurts a day, but Nikki's intake is much higher.  On a bad day I could easily get through three or four six-packs, she said. That adds up to between 18 and 24 yogurts in as many hours.  Nikki explained: I would usually have two for breakfast mixed in with oats, then a couple for lunch and dinner. The rest are in between meals - probably every half an hour when I am home in between my jobs. I have the fruit flavours in the morning and during the day. Then in the evening I love the orange or caramel ones with added chocolate bits. I'm gutted, though, as they have just brought out banoffee flavour and I would have lived off these!  Nikki estimates she spends upwards of &pound30 per week on the light desserts - and she panics  she doesn't have any in the fridge. Every night, pretty much, my husband will ask  we need anything from the shops and yogurts are always on the list, she said. The school worker is mum to Luke, nine, Holly, 10, Jack, 13 and 28-year-old Liam and says she is renowned for her addiction among her friends and family - who think it's hilarious. title: he too young full time
story: News"He is too young for full time education" Mum refuses to send son, 4, to school so can spend more time at homeStanley Hutchinson, 4, was due to start school in September but will spend time at home with his mum and younger brother insteadShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByJoanna LovellNeil Murphy09:39, 19 SEP 2018Updated11:11, 19 SEP 2018NewsEmma Hutchinson with her son Stanley"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum has refused to send her four-year-old son to school this year because he is 'too young for full-time education.' Stanley Hutchinson was due to start school two weeks ago but is currently spending his days at home with mum, Emma, and his younger brother. Emma, 38, says she wants her son to enjoy days of 'fun and freedom' and 'playing in the wild', Hull Live reports . Stanley is a June baby and so is one of the youngest in the school year. He does not have any additional needs, but his parents believe it is in his best interests to start school next year, once he is five and at compulsory school age .  In her blog, Dirt, Diggers and Dinosaurs , his mum explains her reasons for holding him back by applying to defer his admission to school for a year. She starts by saying: We’ve done something that many of our friends and family will view as controversial. We have decided not to send Stanley to school this year. Instead, he will be starting next September when he is five. For the extra year he will be attending preschool part time, playing, bonding with his brothers, playing, exploring, enjoying days out, playing, growing and developing at his own pace. She then answers some of the questions she says she's been asked.  No, Stanley does not have any special educational needs. No, we haven’t ‘held him back’ because he was struggling at preschool. No, it’s not that we can’t bear to let him go, and I want to keep him a baby. No, we aren’t doing it for ourselves and not thinking about what’s best for him. No, we’ve not thrown our dummy out because he didn’t a place at our first choice of school this year... he did. No, we’ve not done what’s easiest for us.   As you can probably tell from the answers above, I’ve had a bit of an ear bashing by some which I hope is mostly fuelled by misinformation and misunderstanding, she says. Explaining her decision, she said: The plain fact is, he’s four. We’ve simply chosen not to send him to school early, we are sending him at school age which  you go back a generation was the absolute norm. I personally believe that in the UK all children start school too early and that we’d be better off following our European neighbours whose children start school at aged seven when they are emotionally and physically ready.  We were recently informed at a preschool parents evening that Stanley  would soon cope with starting school, as he’s really bright. This really hit home for me, a four year old shouldn’t have to cope with anything. Emma, from Hull, Yorkshire, who is expecting another baby, says she decided to write the blog to let other parents know it is possible to prevent your child from starting school at the age of four, as she believes it's not widely known. This year three set of parents have successfully applied to Hull City Council to defer their child's entry to school. Emma said: I’ve had two relative strangers - who I only know through ious kids clubs - tell me that they think it’s amazing, and one who asked me to email her the info so she could then look into it for her daughter. She had no idea that the option was available, which I think is a massive issue. Thanks to a change in DfE legislation, we not only have the choice whether to start his school journey prior to CSA or at CSA but also have the right to request admission into Reception class at CSA rather than Year One, ensuring that he will not lose a vital whole year of early education. I think an extra year of being a child with no responsibility or pressure can only be a good thing. When I read articles about phonics tests in Year one ages five and six and SATS at ages six and seven it makes me so sad. When did being a child become so target driven? Aren’t we told by midwives and health visitors that ‘they all learn at their own pace?' Why does this suddenly change when they enter the school system? The extra year at home will be an extra year of developing emotionally and at his own pace. An extra year of learning through play, exploration and love.  A controversial decision which is a big 'gamble' Emma said she 100 per cent believes she has made the right decision for Stanley, but admits there is a big gamble involved. She said: The BIG gamble in all of this and the only thing that regularly niggles at me is whether we will get offered our first choice school again in the next round of admissions. If we don’t, then will our offered school be happy to support a CSA Reception start, or will they be championing Year 1? The LEA and school would have to provide evidence that missing a whole year of education would be in his best interests. I guess we’ll just have to face any obstacles, and fight the battles as we get to them. However Emma signs the blog post off by saying as she sits there writing the post and watching Stanley performing a puppet show for his brother using three toy dinosaurs, she knows with all certainty that this is the best thing for her child.

story: NewsMoment man 'ploughs car into packed nightclub dancefloor in revenge for being thrown out'Mohammed Abdul, 21, allegedly attempted to storm his way back into a venue he had been thrown out of by charging his car into the premisesShare&nbspByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter20:53, 19 SEP 2018Updated20:55, 19 SEP 2018Newsthis.style.display='none'"/Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in 8CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror/news/uk-news/video/cctv-shows-moment-disgruntled-clubber-13275242,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-M3TH25P,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,bundledCss:false,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx/rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail/F/QVgi9PbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_/,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThis is the moment a man allegedly rammed his car into a packed dancefloor to get revenge for being thrown out of a nightclub.  Jurors were shown footage of Mohammed Abdul, 21, allegedly driving his Suzuki Vitara past bouncers and into revellers. CCTV footage appears to show the vehicle coursing down an alleyway packed with clubbers before later ploughing into the venue itself. From a camera inside Blake's in Gravesend, Kent, the vehicle's front lights can be seen getting closer and closer as dancers mingle, unaware the Suzuki is hurtling towards them.  One man can then be seen spread-eagled on the bonnet, swept off his feet as the Suzuki rams into him from behind. Others are seen fleeing to safety as security guards appear in hot pursuit of the car, shortly before midnight on March 17 this year. The car can be seen reversing, its registration plate hanging off at an angle, as patrons stagger to get to their feet. Some clubbers can be seen appearing to swarm the vehicle and showering it with a volley of thumps, while others look visibly distressed in the corner of the nightclub.  Abdul is on trial at Maidstone Crown Court for attempted murder over the incident which left eight people injured. The court heard he had been ejected from the venue at around 11.40pm for being too drunk. His trial was told that while in a rage and acting aggressively, he threatened bouncers, telling doorman Peter Muro: If I can't come in I'm going to come back and shut this place down and kill you guys. Abdul ed in his vehicle around 10 minutes later and drove at speed down a narrow alleyway by the side of the club, with door staff and clubbers jumping or being pulled out of the way, prosecutor Simon Taylor said.  The alleyway housed a marquee attached to the club with a dance floor and DJ booth, and it was filled with revellers there to see grime rapper Giggs. Abdul, of Deptford, south-east London, accepts he was the driver of the vehicle and has admitted causing serious injury by dangerous driving, jurors heard. But he denies two counts of attempting to murder persons in the vicinity of the club and an alternative charge of attempting to cause grievous bodily harm with intent.

title: mans doorbell locks him out
story: NewsMan's doorbell locks him out of his house - and he's shocked when he discovers the reason whyA man who installed a video doorbell in his home was shocked to discover why it refused him entryShare&nbsp&nbspCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer18:24, 19 SEP 2018NewsA man's doorbell locked him out of his home for a bizarre reason "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email In this day and age you can pretty much get a gadget or a gizmo to do just about anything.   Be it a new Apple Watch that can take an ECG reading , a virtual reality headset or a drone, you can buy all sorts of quirky technology.   One modern advancement, is the video doorbell , which allows people to see who is approaching their front door, from the safety of their own home.  Gone are the days of opening up to cold callers, you can now screen who you do and don't answer the door to. But it appears there are a few faults with the device - as one dad found when his locked him out of his own house.   A Twitter user, named B.J. May shared his amusing story of the tech fail on Twitter.  A Javascript developer, the dad is no stranger to coding and played around with some of the features of his Nest doorbell app to suit his needs. He programmed the device to automatically lock the door  the camera detected an unfamiliar face. But he soon found there was a major flaw in his plan.     On Tuesday the father attempted to get inside the house after checking on his son who was playing in front of the house.  However the doorbell locked the door and wouldn't let him in. So he decided to check the app and see what the problem was - but he wasn't prepared for what he saw.  Instead of his face, the camera had picked up an image of an angry looking Batman from his t-shirt and locked the doors thinking it was a stranger approaching.
